Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Mechanism of Antibiotic Resistance Associated with the Arabidopsis ABC Protein, Atwbc19

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

ABC (ATP binding cassette ) proteins represent a gene family that has greatly expanded in plants, with twice as many members in Arabidopsis and rice (over 120) as any other sequenced genome of a multicellular organism (eg. human, worm, fly). The reason behind the expansion of this family in plants is unknown but hints to kingdom specific evolutionary constraints. This project focuses on the Arabidopsis ABC protein, Atwbc19 (ABCG19), a member of a plant-specific clade. Atwbc19 confers antibiotic resistance but the underlying mechanism is not clear. Preliminary results suggest that Atwbc19 does not function as a transporter but as a translational regulator. Thus the goal of this project is to demonstrate cleavage of Atwbc19 resulting in a soluble ABC protein, confirm its association with the translation apparatus and identify regulated transcripts. Ultimately, a new paradigm for antibiotic resistance in plants may be established.

BROADER IMPACT

The project has three educational objectives. First, long term research opportunities will be provided to undergraduates. Second, a research based course will be developed. And finally, research experiences will be provided in the traditional classroom through an upper level Plant Biology course. Overall, the project will contribute to the strategic goal of the College to increase student participation in research or internships from 30% to 100% by 2015. At the departmental level, the project will contribute to a curriculum that is being significantly revised towards a stronger emphasis on linking research to teaching. Ultimately, one goal is to inspire African American female students to engage in intellectual and personal development that leads them to Graduate School.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to understand the mechanism of antibiotic resistance associated with the Arabidopsis ABC protein, Atwbc19 (ABCG19). Plant genomes typically encode for over 100 ABC proteins but the expansion of the subfamily containing Atwbc19 in Arabidopsis is intriguing. Our preliminary results suggested that Atwbc19 is a member of a plant-specific clade of ABC proteins that do not function as transporters but appear to have gained a new function – that of translational regulators.  Atwbc19 could not be localized in a membrane compartment and in a yeast two-hybrid screen was found to interact with a subunit of eIF3 (eukaryotic initiation factor 3). In this project we confirmed the interaction of Atwb19 with the eIF3 subunit using Bimolecular Fluorescence Complementation (BiFC) assays. We also examined the genome wide effect of the exposure of Arabidopsis seedlings to the antibiotic kanamycin in and established a link between antibiotic exposure and metal uptake. In addition, we identified transcripts whose translation was modulated by kanamycin using the polysomal RNA immunoprecipitation technique. Taken together these findings have expanded our understanding of the function of a group of ABC proteins in plants and plant responses to antibiotics both at the transcriptional and translational level. The project provided research opportunities for 20 undergraduates at Spelman – a Historically Black College for women, 6 of which are now in PhD programs. The project also provided the opportunity to expose student in the regular classroom (upper level Methods in molecular Biology course) to research.
